column5: I had clogged ducts early on in my breastfeeding journey before my son had his tongue tie corrected. I used to take a hot shower, then let my boobs hang down while I pumped. Let gravity help you. You can do it on hands and knees if you can stand it, but I would usually just sit and lean all the way over.

When I was trying to lose weight before my wedding I actually used the meal plan they had given me in recovery as a starting point. Then I knew I would be getting at least close to enough. I broke it down by week instead of day, so instead of 2 fruits a day, it was 14 fruits a week. That way I had a little more flexibly. Worked for me!

I have a 10 day old newborn. As of today we have locked it down. No more visitors, including our parents. There is too much exposure out there and not enough info on how the virus can affect a newborn or someone who just gave birth. My husband has been running errands as necessary, but I make him wash his hands and change his clothes when he gets home. People have asked to come visit and Iâ€™ve said no. They can meet him in a few weeks when this all dies down, but if everyone doesnâ€™t do their part now itâ€™s going to get way worse. Cancel whatever you need to cancel to feel safe and comfortable. I was diagnosed with Velamentous Cord Insertion at my anatomy scan at 19 weeks. At that point they were concerned about everything under the sun. I was scheduled for monthly growth scans to monitor babyâ€™s progress. At my 23 week growth scan they were able to get better pictures and changed the diagnosis to Marginal Cord Insertion. Babyâ€™s growth was good and MCI is less severe than VCI so I didnâ€™t have another growth scan until 32 weeks. At 32 he was still growing well, but the insertion was still iffy so they left the MCI diagnosis so they can be aware of it at delivery, and more for my safety when they deliver the placenta than babyâ€™s. I think Drs only get concerned when MCI/VCI babies are under the 10th percentile so low end of normal sounds fine to me!

There are so many times that Iâ€™ve felt utterly disgusting in my growing body. I havenâ€™t resorted to any ED behaviors, because I know itâ€™s not good for my unborn son, but the thoughts are there. Coconut water has been a huge help for me. Drink it before eating anything.
Unfortunately, no. We get it at Petco.
We were using the hills science diet sensitive skin and stomach one before we switched. Now she is on Acana.

What is the protein in the food? Poultry allergies are very common. The sensitive skin food did nothing for our girl because it was still a chicken protein. We switched to dog food with only fish protein and our dogs skin improved very quickly. You can try uncommon proteins like rabbit, fish, or venison. 

We also supplement with coconut oil. She wonâ€™t eat it in her food, but I melt some coconut oil and natural peanut butter together, and freeze it in an ice cube mould (of course I bought a cute paw print one...). Coconut oil can be used topically too. It has antibacterial and antifungal properties. 

For seasonal/outdoor allergies you can give a small amount (1tsp or less) of LOCAL honey which can help expose them to local pollen and may help them react less. Itâ€™s also anti inflammatory and antibacterial. 

No medical degree or vet training, just a dog mama with a allergic Am. Staffie! Hope that helps!!
Absolutely right there with you. 30 weeks and people at work were asking if I was coming back after Christmas....umm, yes, I still have all of Jan and Feb before my maternity leave starts.

I agree with sikkerhet for two reasons. 

1) When I was in (outpatient) treatment I was exhausted, physically and emotionally ALL the time. I can home from my program and immediately went to sleep, almost daily. Not sure if this is the norm or not, but there is no way I would have been able to participate in or maintain any kind of romantic relationship. 

2) In a weird and twisted way, the eating disorder is kinda like a boyfriend. Obviously not a good one, heâ€™s a abusive prick, but for me it was like having an sadistic partner in my head all the time. So, jumping into a relationship with someone who is â€œbreaking upâ€ with their relationship with food and their body may not make a ton of sense. You probably donâ€™t want to be the person to replace the eating disorder in her life. She needs to develop a strong sense of who she is without the ED before diving into a new relationship. You donâ€™t want to be the ED rebound, you know? Iâ€™m not sure if Iâ€™m making any sense here, but hopefully I am!

Yes, itâ€™s a subscription service. It comes to your home as often as youâ€™d like. You can put your style choices and fit preferences into the app so it knows what you are looking for. Same thing happened to me (F, 30) as a teen. I am so sorry you have to deal with this. BUT there are ED diagnosis that donâ€™t require you to be underweight. It used to be called EDNOS (Eating disorder not otherwise specified) but now I think itâ€™s called OSFED (otherwise specified feeding and eating disorder) I know internet research for medical stuff is not always the best idea, but maybe look into those? Not sure where you are located but the NEDA website may have some reputable resources. I was treated through Renfrew and they have multiple locations as well. Good luck!!
